G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter of this Complaint pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31; G.L. c. 215, §§ 3 and 6; G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (if applicable), and the Court’s general equity powers in matters of custody and parenting time.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3 and 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter of this Complaint pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31; G.L. c. 215, §§ 3 and 6; G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (if applicable), and the Court’s general equity powers in matters of custody and parenting time.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20 (if applicable).proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter of this Complaint pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31; G.L. c. 215, §§ 3 and 6; G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (if applicable), and the Court’s general equity powers in matters of custody and parenting time.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a Probate and Family Court may revise and modify a judgment as to the care, custody, and maintenance of minor children “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal decisions under G.L. c. 208, § 30, the words “upon cause shown” mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child, and it then describes the best interests of the child as the central and paramount concern guiding the analysis. While Yannas is a removal case rather than a generic custody-modification case, the court’s reasoning treats best interests as the governing standard for the parenting/custody determination at issue, consistent with the cited proposition for Massachusetts custody/parenting-time matters.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the origin and role of the “best interests of the child” standard in Massachusetts custody law, describing it as the governing principle in custody and visitation decisions. It cites Yannas and other cases for the proposition that the child’s best interests are the paramount concern, and it analyzes G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) as adding statutory considerations that guide—but do not replace or limit—the best‑interests standard. This directly supports the claimed proposition that best interests are the paramount and governing standard in custody and parenting‑time determinations in Massachusetts.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’). … The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider…”}

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses parental fitness and the relationship between fitness and the child’s best interests, but it does not state that the best interests standard is the paramount or governing standard in all custody and parenting‑time determinations and modifications. Instead, it emphasizes that when the State seeks to remove a child from a parent, parental unfitness must be clearly shown and that custody may not be transferred simply because another custodian is better. Thus, it does not serve as direct authority for the broad, across‑the‑board proposition claimed.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.relevant_excerpt: “State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.” … “In that sense, the fitness of parents and the best interests of the child are related. … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the standard for modifying custody or parenting‑time orders (material and substantial change plus best interests of the child). Schuler, however, deals exclusively with modification of alimony and child support under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 37, and articulates only the requirement of a material change in circumstances for support/alimony modification. It does not discuss custody, parenting time, or a best‑interests analysis for changing such orders, so it does not support the specific custody/parenting‑time proposition cited.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952).”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion addresses the criteria for making an initial custody determination (focusing on the child’s welfare and best interests) and reverses a custody award for lack of appropriate findings. It does not discuss modification of an existing custody or parenting‑time order, nor does it require a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior judgment. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about the standard for modification of prior custody orders.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the statutory and doctrinal standard for modifying a prior custody judgment: there must be a material and substantial change in circumstances and the modification must be in the best interests of the children. The court cites G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related precedent, applies the ‘material and substantial change’ test to the mother’s rehabilitation, and then analyzes whether the resulting modification serves the children’s best interests. This directly supports the proposition for which it is cited.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ … When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children.”

Schuler, 382 Mass. at 369\u201370.proposition: Mother’s changed work and educational status represents a significant and positive change in circumstances, improving her ability to meet the Child’s day‑to‑day needs, to maintain routines, and to provide a stable caregiving presence. See, e.g., Schuler, 382 Mass. at 369–70 (change in financial and employment situation can support modification); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 190 (1998) (stability and predictability are important to children’s best interests).

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 190.proposition: Mother’s changed work and educational status represents a significant and positive change in circumstances, improving her ability to meet the Child’s day‑to‑day needs, to maintain routines, and to provide a stable caregiving presence. See, e.g., Schuler, 382 Mass. at 369–70 (change in financial and employment situation can support modification); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 190 (1998) (stability and predictability are important to children’s best interests).
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 190.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rosenberg v. Merida does not discuss a parent’s changed work or educational status, nor does it frame any analysis around a parent’s improved ability to meet a child’s day‑to‑day needs or provide a stable caregiving presence. Its substantive holdings concern (1) crediting Social Security disability dependency benefits toward child support, (2) authority to attach assets to secure support and college expenses, and (3) the need for adequate findings to support a custody modification. Although it mentions the statutory standard of “best interests of the child,” it does not develop any principle about the importance of stability and predictability in the specific way the proposition claims. The citation is therefore inapt for that proposition.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 190.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … However, we shall not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’ ”}

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 403–04 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The improved housing arrangement constitutes a material and positive change in circumstances relevant to the Child’s physical comfort, privacy, and emotional security, and supports an increase in overnights and overall parenting time with Mother. See, e.g., Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 403–04 (1981) (examining adequacy of home environment and living arrangements as part of best‑interest analysis).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss a parent’s improved or changed housing arrangement as a material, positive change in circumstances warranting increased parenting time. In Rolde the home and living arrangements are considered only in the context of property division and a static custody/visitation determination, not as a modification based on improved housing or as a factor specifically tied to physical comfort, privacy, and emotional security to justify more overnights. Thus, citing Rolde for that specific proposition overstates its holding and use of the home‑environment factor.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: The judge found the wife has been the “primary nurturing parent” and “primary caretaker” and that the children have the “strongest bond” with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children. Although the husband had had involvement with the child rearing functions and responsibilities, the judge concluded that because the parties have basic fundamental differences...

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842\u20134.proposition: In assessing the child’s best interests, the Court considers all relevant factors, including but not limited to: the child’s age and developmental needs; the child’s relationship with each parent; the stability of each parent’s home; each parent’s ability to meet the child’s emotional, educational, and physical needs; the parties’ willingness to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent; and, where appropriate, the child’s own preferences, with due regard to the child’s age and maturity. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842–43; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 231–33 (1998).

Ardizoni, 40 Mass. App. Ct. at 738\u2013.proposition: As children grow, their best interests can require different parenting schedules, routines, and contact with each parent than those that were appropriate when they were much younger. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842–43 (recognizing that passage of time and children’s maturing needs can be relevant to modification); Ardizoni, 40 Mass. App. Ct. at 738–39.

Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 9.raw_text: Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 993, 994 (1984)
Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 9.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a child’s well‑reasoned and voluntary preferences about parenting time may be considered, particularly for an older child, as one factor among many in determining best interests. See, e.g., Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 993, 994 (1984); Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 564–66 (2000).
Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 9.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss, mention, or analyze the child’s own preferences, nor does it address how a child’s stated wishes (well‑reasoned or otherwise) factor into a best‑interests analysis. The court focuses instead on parental fitness, the child’s health, and the importance of the natural parent–child bond. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that Massachusetts law considers an older child’s voluntary parenting‑time preferences as one factor among many.
Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 9.relevant_excerpt:
Finding both the foster parents and the biological mother “fit” to parent the child, the judge concluded that the child’s best interests would be served by returning her to her biological mother.

Contrary to the appellants’ contention, a probate judge may allow the bond between a child and a biological parent to tip in favor of the biological parent the balance between parties fit to have custody. “In invoking the ‘best interests of the child’ the Legislature did not intend to disregard the ties between the child and its natural parent.”

Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 564\u20.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a child’s well‑reasoned and voluntary preferences about parenting time may be considered, particularly for an older child, as one factor among many in determining best interests. See, e.g., Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 993, 994 (1984); Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 564–66 (2000).
Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 564\u20.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Adoption of Vito discusses when a judge may use equitable powers to order postadoption contact between a child and biological parents, focusing on existing emotional bonds and best interests. It does not address, even in dicta, consideration of a child’s own stated, voluntary preferences about parenting time, nor does it distinguish older versus younger children on that basis. Accordingly, this case does not support the specific proposition that Massachusetts law recognizes a child’s well‑reasoned custodial preferences as a factor in determining best interests.
Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 564\u20.relevant_excerpt: "Where, as here, the child has formed strong, nurturing bonds with his preadoptive family, and there is little or no evidence of a significant, existing bond with the biological parent, judicial exercise of equitable power to require postadoption contact would usually be unwarranted.... A necessary condition is a finding, supported by the evidence, that continued contact is currently in the best interests of the child." (431 Mass. at 563–64).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: In assessing the child’s best interests, the Court considers all relevant factors, including but not limited to: the child’s age and developmental needs; the child’s relationship with each parent; the stability of each parent’s home; each parent’s ability to meet the child’s emotional, educational, and physical needs; the parties’ willingness to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent; and, where appropriate, the child’s own preferences, with due regard to the child’s age and maturity. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842–43; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 231–33 (1998).

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 844.proposition: A parent’s willingness and ability to foster the Child’s relationship with the other parent is a significant factor in assessing the best interests of the child. See, e.g., Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 844; Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 404–05.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 844.support_reasoning: The opinion is an extended discussion of the best-interests standard under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), focusing on primary caretaker status, stability, and continuity of care. It does not identify, discuss, or weigh either parent’s willingness or ability to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent as a factor. Because that co‑parenting/fostering‑relationship consideration is not mentioned or treated as significant in the court’s reasoning, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition cited.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 844.relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s custody award was based on his conclusion that these arrangements were in the best interests of the child. This conclusion was based, in turn, on a number of findings, including, inter alia, that the mother and the father are not able to make shared decisions relative to their daughter’s welfare, and joint legal custody would not be in Kali’s interest; that the mother provides well for Kali’s physical needs, is concerned with her health and educational issues… [and] that it is important that Kali be able to spend as much time as possible with her father on weekends, holidays, and during school vacations to continue to foster their close and positive relationship.”}

Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 404\u201305.proposition: A parent’s willingness and ability to foster the Child’s relationship with the other parent is a significant factor in assessing the best interests of the child. See, e.g., Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 844; Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 404–05.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 231\u2013.proposition: No evidence suggests that increasing Mother’s parenting time and overnights would be harmful to the Child; instead, all indications from the Child’s statements, therapeutic input, and Mother’s current circumstances show that such modification would advance the Child’s welfare. See, e.g., Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 231–33; Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. at 766–67.

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. at 766\u20.raw_text: Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. at 766–67
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. at 766\u20.proposition: No evidence suggests that increasing Mother’s parenting time and overnights would be harmful to the Child; instead, all indications from the Child’s statements, therapeutic input, and Mother’s current circumstances show that such modification would advance the Child’s welfare. See, e.g., Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 231–33; Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. at 766–67.

Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. at 564\u2013.proposition: Mother also requests that the Court consider, in its discretion, whether an interview of the Child, appointment of a guardian ad litem, or consideration of the Child’s letter to the Court is appropriate and consistent with her best interests, in light of her age and maturity, as allowed under Massachusetts law. See, e.g., Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. at 564–66; Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. at 994.

Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. a.raw_text: Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. at 994
Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. a.proposition: Mother also requests that the Court consider, in its discretion, whether an interview of the Child, appointment of a guardian ad litem, or consideration of the Child’s letter to the Court is appropriate and consistent with her best interests, in light of her age and maturity, as allowed under Massachusetts law. See, e.g., Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. at 564–66; Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. at 994.
Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. a.support_reasoning: The opinion in Adoption of a Minor concerns competing adoption/custody petitions between foster parents and a biological mother and the application of the “best interests of the child” standard. It does not discuss interviewing the child, appointing a guardian ad litem, or considering a child’s letter or stated preferences in relation to age and maturity. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the procedural/discretionary point asserted in the proposition.
Adoption of a Minor, 17 Mass. App. Ct. a.relevant_excerpt: The probate judge found, among other things: that the child is in excellent emotional and physical health; that the biological mother is “able and prepared to resume caring for her daughter”; that the foster parents have “the ability, capacity, fitness and readiness to assume parental responsibility” for the child; that the length of time which the child has spent away from her biological mother does not justify the termination of the mother’s parental rights; and that, on balance, it is in the child’s best interests to be returned to her biological mother.
